author: Jenny Wiggins
title: Transurban board loses former Orica CEO Ian Smith
text:
Former Orica boss Ian Smith has suddenly left the board of Transurban Rob Homer by Jenny Wiggins Former Orica chief executive Ian Smith has resigned suddenly from the board of tollroad group Transurban a day ahead of its annual results.
Mr Smith, who had been on Transurban's board since January 2012, left explosives maker Orica in March after incidents involving aggressive behaviour .
Orica's new CEO, Alberto Calderon, shocked investors last week by taking write-downs up to $1.65 billion , forcing Orica shares down 13.5 percent.
Mr Smith's departure from Transurban is effective immediately.
Transurban chairman Lindsay Maxsted said Mr Smith had brought "valuable skills and experience" to the board, particularly in relation to major project development and project management.
Transurban's board is "hopeful" of announcing the appointment of one or two new non-executive directors by the end of December, Mr Maxsted added.
Transurban reports its annual results on Tuesday.
Separately, engineering group UGL has added a second female director, Jane Harvey, as new chairman Kate Spargo moves ahead with plans to diversify the contractor's board.
 Ms Harvey is currently a non-executive director of DUET Finance and IOOF Holdings, where she chairs the audit committees. She has previously been a director at David Jones, Medibank Private, Boom Logistics and several Victorian government boards.
UGL has also appointed its senior counsel, barrister Robert Kaye, to its board. Mr Kaye is currently chairman of Collins Food and Paperlinx, and a non-executive director at magnesium manufacturer Magontec.
The new board appointments , combined with the earlier appointment of engineer John Cooper in April, would help "lead the new strategic direction" of UGL as a standalone engineering and maintenance services company, Ms Spargo said.
"We are now well progressed with the renewal of the board."
Existing director Doug McTaggart, who joined the board in September 2012, will resign from the board on August 3 due to other board commitments.
Ms Spargo, who replaced Trevor Rowe as UGL's chairman after the 2014 AGM, wants to create a more diverse board to oversee the company's development following the sale of property arm DTZ, which has left it with just 9,000 employees compared with 55,000 previously.
UGL reports annual results on August 24.
